» The Software Industry Hits Middle Age

What was the first sign? It might have been Steve Jobs’ return to Apple, a sadder but wiser prodigal CEO. It could even have been back in 1995, when IBM did the first unfriendly takeover of a software company, as Jim Manzi went for the dough and sold Lotus to Big Blue.

Certainly, by the time Larry Ellison announced that Oracle’s future lay in mergers, the time had already come. Larry proved himself right, and doubters wrong, by his ability to swallow most of his competitors and grow Oracle’s share price.

How old is Oracle? This is one you’ll win bets on at the next cocktail party. The company was incorporated in 1977, as Software Development Laboratories, making Oracle 30 years old this year. Larry had been inspired by the Codd and Date bible on (relational) database structures, and made his first sale of Oracle 2 (the first version; even then the company had problems with telling customers the truth). Today it is the second-largest software company, behind Microsoft.

If none of the little rabbit ears in then-still-young tech land had gone up before, they definitely went up after the Big Bad Wolf ate PeopleSoft, and Siebel Systems, and Sleepycat, and – well, for those who haven’t been paying close attention, here is the current list, from the Software Mergers and Acquisitions Hall of Fame:

By any measure, when Oracle finished its long and bloody PeopleSoft chase, the gun had gone off in the next M and A–driven phase in the world of software. But even then Oracle was a standout, and Larry remained (as he does today, almost by a palpable and public personal desire) the Bad Boy of the industry.

Bill Gates’ most common refrain to Wall Street analysts, from the first day Microsoft went public, was that the company would eventually face “the law of big numbers,” referring to the difficulty of continuing to post consistently large percentage growth figures as size increased.

This single mathematical issue is what drives nearly all the M and A activity on Wall Street, regardless of rationale. And this kind of activity is what uniquely typifies Software Hitting Middle Age: companies having hit a size that prevents continued, historically consistent growth rates.

As Microsoft now launches out onto a full-time, radar-up M and A program, it’s safe to say: We’re There.

You say three-quarters of all mergers fail? Who cares? After all, if we asked about the financial fate of the CEOs who did those mergers, we’d find that virtually all of the acquired CEOs took a huge golden parachute and went off to buy their own island, while the acquiring CEO used the transaction to hide any current screw-ups and misdemeanors (or felonies) he/she had been propagating on the shareholders.

It’s a real win/win, when you see it through the eyes of the people at the levers.

And the bankers? They always make money, even when the companies, officers, employees, and shareholders get screwed. After all, theirs comes off the top. That’s why the bankers, like hyenas, are constantly prodding companies to take the next step, either toward IPOs or purchases and sales. Since this activity is rarely good for the company and its stakeholders, this Middle Age thing can be tough on those who don’t live in Connecticut (home of all hedge-fund managers and investment bankers).

I had a couple of calls from journalists this week that weave nicely into this story. The first came from Todd Bishop, at the Seattle Post-Intelligencer, wanting to talk about tech employees’ apparent donation preference for Obama. (You can see his story at <http://seattlepi.nwsource.com/business/358889_software14.html>.)

He recalled a conversation we had during the Microsoft purchase of aQuantive, reminding me I had predicted then that MS would continue with large acquisitions now that they had started, and here we were with the Yahoo! bid (and with the Tellme purchase done). I guess most people hadn’t expected the buying trend to continue, but really, the company has little choice.

Not that the transactions themselves always make sense, but I’d suggest that, in general, they do. Unlike GE, which is having a bit of trouble making conglomerates look good this week (or year, or three years; Hello, Jeff?), most tech match-ups have a real technology road map driving the purchase, and often a complementary customer set that will fit well into technology dependencies. (By this, I mean if you buy and link their favorite products to yours, their hearts and minds will follow, in Nixonian fashion.)

It isn’t hard to understand the Microsoft/Yahoo! bid: MS wants a larger share of the online ad revenue pie, which is already huge and which will be five times larger in ten years, as paper media crumble or move onto the Net.

It’s easy money; go get it.

The other journalist call came this morning from my friend Steve Lohr at the New York Times, who seemed to have discovered a $100MM “flight insurance” premium MS may have paid to keep employees happy during the $800MM purchase of Tellme Networks. He wanted to know whether a 12% premium was too much to pay in off-budget closing costs, and whether this was keeping MS from raising its current price.

I suggested that MS probably did have to pay a higher premium for its Valley purchases than, say, Google, because of a perception that people would rather work for the latter. I also said this was the result not of how the current MS operates, but probably one more cost item from what I used to call “Bill’s Billion Dollar Mistake,” which by now should be called “Bill’s $50B Mistake.” That mistake was to kill competitors rather than beat them; to be ruthless, rather than tough.

If there is a premium gap in off-budget closing costs, we could call it the Microsoft Premium. If Google might have to pay, say, 8% in flight insurance, and MS has to pay 12% to close the deal, that gives us an additional 4% Microsoft Premium. It could be higher, because I suspect that Google might find its own number to be zero; that targets are actually happy to be bought. In that case, the MS Premium would be 12%.

Add that to the Yahoo! bid, and you’re talking serious money.

But I don’t quite track with Steve’s question: it may be that this cost is assumed, even off-budget. I think MS’ reluctance to raise its bid comes from a presumption that, once official price negotiations begin, it will then have to do so, and doing so early will just double the delta spent. They’re probably right.

I told Steve Lohr that the MS/Yahoo! fight would end up with MS prevailing, but that it would be as protracted as the Oracle/PeopleSoft battle.

But there is a much larger problem that MS, and the rest of the Middle Agers, face, even when transactions make sense, are tough to do, and finally get done.

Once you start on this path, you just can’t stop. And that’s one of the big problems with the tech industry at middle age.

For any given deal, assuming you beat all the odds and it’s well-chosen and well-implemented, there will be an initial bump for the acquirer, as revenues are added, headcount is cut, and cross-sales opportunities are pursued. Let’s say that takes a year or two.

Then the bump’s over, but you’ve really increased your size this time. Uh-oh.

Now you have to do it again, to keep those large numbers up, but you’re much larger, so either the company you buy next has to be even larger, or you have to do it more often, which starts the next turn of the Great Mandela, and the next big bump in earnings, and fall-off, and then ---

Welcome to Wall St. capitalism, smoothed quarterly earnings, deceptive management practices, endless M and A exercises, and no way to get off the treadmill except going private. All thanks to the law of large numbers.

Welcome to Middle Age.

Your comments are always welcome.

Sincerely,

Mark R. Anderson

» The Fat Pipe Wins. Next Question?

Let’s see, which bet should you make: that people will suddenly find their thirst for bandwidth sated, just when the Old Phonies run out of capacity on their ancient plants, OR that bandwidth appetite will continue to grow, fueled by bundling voice with entertainment, Internet access, fax, increased graphic content on the Web, the move to High Definition Video, gaming popularity, and the switch to IPTV?

It’s obviously a tough choice.

Or at least it is if you’re running AT&T (“T”), long my least-favorite telephone company, not long ago underlining that positioning by RAISING prices on bandwidth, as it drops everywhere else in the world, and from every other vendor.

On comes Verizon, continuing to benefit from its growing investment in glass (now approaching $23B for its FiOS net), with rumors that it will raise the poker ante from 50 Mbps at $90/month in NYC (and $140 in other states) to 100 Mbps.

For SNSers who like our updated “Rabbit Ratio” ($ per Mbits per second) as a global measure, that puts Verizon/NYC at 1.8. In other states, it’s 2.8.

AT&T charges $150 for 50Mbps, giving it a nice round 3.0. (Low is good in this game.)

Comcast, late to the fiber game, still gets points for playing, and has cobbled together a multi-pipe multiplexing arrangement that, although kludgy, seems able to push it back into competition with Verizon at 50.

Meanwhile, back at the twisted pair and coax ranch, T and TimeWarner are going to be even less happy when Verizon’s new field equipment, rated at 400 Mbps, hits the streets. (See “Quotes.”)

TW spokesperson Alex Dudley claims that “current speeds are more than adequate,” and T’s faceman Michael Coe says consumers may not be able to benefit from fat pipes because the Net might be clogged somewhere else.

No, I’m not kidding.

T says offering lower speeds at lower prices is the future, 1.5 M for $20 (a record Rabbit Ratio of 13.3).

So: which will it be? Verizon.

» Trade Down, China Up

The globe is spinning to a stop, if you are counting world trade.

According to the Bureau for Economic Policy Analysis, a Dutch research institute, global trade growth for the last three months of 2007 increased at an annualized rate of 0.2% vs. the prior quarter. The prior quarter’s measure had been 6.9%.

This indicator is thought to cover 97% of trade in goods, comprising more than 80% of total world trade. The EPA noted that imports into both the U.S. and Europe fell in the last three months of the year. YTY trade growth maxed out at 9.7% in November of 2006. If trade actually slows, it will be the first time since the 2001 U.S. dotcom debacle.

It is suggested that global trade growth runs at about 2x GDP growth, so you can back those figures out if you like.

Well, you might say, does that include Net Commerce?

If you think doing so would automatically favor the U.S. or Europe, you may wrong, according to a new release from firm BDA, using data from the China Internet Network Information Center suggesting that, at least in users, China has now taken the lead internationally.

Based on a declining edge at the end of 2007 (216MM U.S. vs. 210MM China), BDA calculates that, as of two weeks ago, “China has comfortably passed the U.S. as the world’s largest Internet population,” according to analyst Bin Liu.

BDA suggests that Net Commerce will indeed be the next boom segment of the Chinese economy, as a result of this online market growth.

Experience in Japan might lead one to be slightly more conservative in linking spending to lurking, I’d suggest, but it would not surprise me to see spending per capita in Chinese cities run higher than in Japan.

For that reason, and because users are not dollars (or Yuan), I’ll suggest that China remains a year or more behind the U.S. in total dollars spent in Net Commerce, but there is no reason to think the Chinese won’t also catch up in this more important regard relatively soon.

» BP To Get Putinized

We might as well make it a verb: what happens to oil companies with deals in Russia.

Without wasting time or going into the past, Dictator Putin has nationalized every oil field and operation within reach (old news) except for TNK-BP, which BP shareholders were quietly hoping might somehow survive, as they whistled past the graveyard of the Kremlin.

And now – drum roll – first for the fake charges:

Police raided BP Moscow HQ a couple of weeks ago, looking for evidence of “industrial espionage” (or, no doubt, underused toilet paper).

Then the FSB (i.e., the democratically elected federal government, a.k.a. the Kleptocracy) arrested two British-educated brothers (Ilya and Alexander Zaslavsky) with BP links. Both are Oxford-educated; the latter runs the British Alumni Club, under the British Council.

Then comes the environmental guy, Oleg Mitvol, the same stooge who used the same permit tricks to re-jigger ownership against Shell in Sakhalin-2.

BP, with 50% ownership of the JV, is going down. The only question is how far.

Instead of being completely driven out of the deal, the Russians will hope they’ll stay in as minority partner, shut up and do as they’re told, take a fraction of the profit, and continue to bring the necessary technology and expertise to the table.

I was telling a friend this week that I still have colleagues in investment banking who think Russia is a great place to invest – if you stay away from oil.

It reminds me of the story about the Nazis, and the pastor who said he didn’t complain when they went after the Jews, and then the Catholics, etc. Our banking friends are fooling themselves if they think the new and democratically elected President Medvedev will be any different, or will cease to go after any sector with money in it.

First oil, then all mineral resources; let’s see, next, well, it might just be ---

You!

» U.S. Ad Spending Flat

As Microsoft, Yahoo!, Google, AOL, and News Corp can all attest, ad spending is what it is all about. Normally, this is a moving target, but not in 2007, according to figures just released by TNS Media Intelligence.

For the year, ad spend was up only 0.2% to $149B; in the fourth quarter, they were down year to year by 0.1%.

Who is losing the most, the fastest? You guessed it: newspapers, down 5.6% to $26B for the year. Ad dollar revenues also fell in television and radio. (Internet ad revenues were up, somewhere in the 25% range, a category not covered in the TNS report.)

Who was responsible? Everyone, really, but here are six of the Top Ten that spent less on ads in 2007: General Motors, TimeWarner, Ford Motor, AT&T, Walt Disney, News Corp.

What’s ahead in this category? I think we’ll see continued increases in online ad revenues and spend, in the area of up 23% for 2008. As for traditional media, I would expect this year (2008) to be down in the U.S., with print continuing to lead the pack. Overall, we may move into negative ad numbers this year, with total U.S. ad spending down 3-5%.

Re: ***SNS*** The Wave Age, Part II

Mark,

Regarding your comments [in last week’s Ethermail]:

Part 1: Convert a couple hundred million–point pollution sources into a few hundred, by driving electric transport vehicles. Which leaves:

Part 2. Invest heavily in cleaning up the power sources.

I agree completely. And I do think most people get it. I think the concern I have (and I admit freely I am probably biased): we seem to chase alternatives almost as if they are social fads at the expense of address the boring, non-glamorous but very important Part 2 you mentioned above.

If we could generate the same excitement about cleaning up power plants as we had two years ago for ethanol plants, we would have moved the effort on cleaning up the power sources a great deal. I am not suggesting we should not be excited about ethanol or any other alternative, in fact we need all the excitement we can generate on anything regarding energy, but we also need to put more emphasis on your Part 2 now along with working on part 1.

Respectfully

Randy Foutch

CEO

Laredo Petroleum

Tulsa, OK

Randy,

Your comments on this are right on target. When you refer to “excitement,” that implies consumer education. Historically, the “excitement” behind things like ethanol, I am afraid, came from mega lobbying firms representing the ag industry.

Can normal people – the voters – gain the same traction with Congress, even if they do get excited? What matters more, 100 letters from constituents or a check for $100k to some nameless re-election PAC by the coal industry?

I wonder if the best way to do this is either pressure (mount a pro–nuclear power move that cuts prior suppliers out completely, la France and Japan) or work directly with coal and gas suppliers to recruit their support and enthusiasm for a new generation of plant technologies.

As a gas guy, you probably have an opinion on how you, and your colleagues, would see this. Are they ready for a change?

Many thanks for writing in. You remain one of our few beacons in the petro wilderness.

Mark Anderson

Mark,

While all this is great, I’m not sure the Wave Age will really start until we have a generation of people educated from the start on wave theory, non-deterministic systems, probability functions, etc.

Today we still teach classical science at the middle school/high school level -- very deterministic models of chemistry, physics, etc.

Then when you get to college, at some point you have to rip all this framework out of your head and relearn materials science and physics from the bottom up based on quantum theory, waves, etc. All those old models of chemistry and materials just get in the way at this point.

Imagine what people will be able to achieve if we have the right tools and framework at the beginning.

John Ludwig

Partner

Ignition Partners

Bellevue, WA

John,

You said it perfectly.

And since you’ve said it, let me add a bit to the rant.

How is it that society continues to add layer after layer of scientific and technical complexity to our knowledge base, but never changes what is taught in K-12? How will children in the future (or today) ever learn what is known if they don’t have more exposure to modern knowledge in their early years?

But you’ve said it best: the problem is not only one of quantity, but also of quality. Students are not exposed to the most basic concepts of modern science and technology in K-12, or even in much of undergraduate work. Want to learn about the basics of quantum mechanics, heralded by everyone from psychiatrists to physicists to investment gurus?

Well, too bad, because you’ll probably have to wait until graduate school before you get any real exposure.

Conversely (and I’ve shared this with Seymour Papert, who seems to delightedly agree): What is calculus? It is a tool, invented by Leibniz and or Newton, to discover areas under a curve, or rates of change.

That’s the good news. The bad news: it is only useful, even in the most adept hands, for the most basic shapes and problems. If you try to use calculus with almost anything from nature, it breaks (the area under a coastline, or inside a leaf?). Which is too bad, since the world is 99.9% natural shapes.

Guess what we have today? Computer screens. Want to solve those insolvable problems? OK, here goes:

Put the leaf shape on the screen.

Count the pixels inside the leaf.

Multiply by area per pixel.

Takes about a millionth of a second.

Now explain to me why students should spend three or four years studying calculus. What a HUGE waste of time, to master an outdated and fairly useless toolset.

OK, end of rant.

You are right; we need to revolutionize what we teach children, and how we do it. Frankly, I don’t see us getting there until we achieve the Inkwell goal of one computer per student, all connected to the Net. These kids need a direct connection to digitized knowledge, and to the best teachers – and teaching techniques – in the world.

Mark Anderson

Phillip Hollsworth offered this good idea. This makes MUCH MORE SENSE than the ‘don’t buy gas on a certain day’ campaign that was going around last April or May! It’s worth your consideration. Join the resistance!!!!

I hear we are going to hit close to $ 1.50 a litre by next summer, and it might go higher!! Want gasoline prices to come down?

We need to take some intelligent, united action. The oil companies just laughed at that because they knew we wouldn’t continue to

‘hurt’ ourselves by refusing to buy gas.

It was more of an inconvenience to us than it was a problem for them. BUT, whoever thought of this idea has come up with a plan that can really work. Please read on and join with us!

By now you’re probably thinking gasoline priced at about $1.20 is super cheap. Me too! It is currently $1.05 for regular unleaded in my

town.

Now that the oil companies and the OPEC nations have conditioned us to think that the cost of a litre of gas is CHEAP at $1 .05- $1.20, we need to take aggressive action to teach them that BUYERS control the marketplace... not sellers.

With the price of gasoline going up more each day, we consumers need to take action.

The only way we are going to see the price of gas come down is if we hit someone in the pocketbook by not purchasing their gas! And, we can do that WITHOUT hurting ourselves.

How? Since we all rely on our cars, we can’t just stop buying gas.

But we CAN have an impact on gas prices if we all act together to force a price war.

Here’s the idea: For the rest of this year, DON’T purchase ANY gasoline from the two biggest companies, ESSO [Exxon] and SHELL.

If they are not selling any gas, they will be inclined to reduce their prices. If they reduce their prices, the other companies will have to follow suit.

But to have an impact, we need to reach literally millions of ESSO [Exxon] and SHELL gas buyers. It’s really simple to do! Now, don’t wimp out on me at this point...keep reading and I’ll explain how simple it is to reach millions of people!!

I am sending this note to 30 people. If each of us send it to at least ten more (30 x 10 = 300) ... and those 300 send it to at least ten more (300 x10 = 3,000)...and so on, by the time the message reaches the sixth group of people, we will have reached over THREE MILLION consumers.

If those three million get excited and pass this on to ten friends each, then 30 million people will have been contacted!

Again, all you have to do is send this to 10 people. That’s all!

(If you don’t understand how we can reach 30 million and all you have to do is send this to 10 people.... Well, let’s face it, you just aren’t a mathematician. But I am. So trust me on this one.)

How long would all that take? If each of us sends this e-mail out to ten more people within one day of receipt, all 30 MILLION people could conceivably be contacted within the next 8 days !!!

I’ll bet you didn’t think you and I had that much potential, did you! Acting together we can make a difference.

If this makes sense to you, please pass this message on. I suggest that we not buy from ESSO [Exxon] / SHELL UNTIL THEY LOWER THEIR PRICES TO THE $1.08 RANGE AND KEEP THEM DOWN. THIS CAN REALLY WORK.

Keep it going

From Geoffrey Ballard

[Ballard Engineering

Vancouver, BC]

I hope it works.

[Analyst

Calgary, Alberta, Canada]

Alex,

I’ve enjoyed Stratfor for years. In this case, George Friedman seems to be saying that, because of a few other events and large troop exercises/buildups, someone is about to start another Middle East war.

Personally, I think Israel is completely out of control, and whatever restraint might have previously come from the U.S. as its partner is now replaced by the “preemptive war” doctrine of the current administration.

Shoot first, think later.

The question may be this: having destroyed his father’s family name in politics, will Bush Jr. multiply his adventures in a final blaze of misled neocon adventures? While the neocons have been cleaned out of the Pentagon like so many rats (with one about to be convicted of spying for Israel), Cheney’s office remains well-stocked with them. If you think Dick is running the country, which I do, this means bad things can still happen.

Is Friedman’s concern warranted? Absolutely. I would tend to discount some of the points he raises as worry nodes: once we put the Sixth Fleet off Lebanon, it makes some sense that Syria would launch an exercise, since it runs Lebanon, and wants to keep running it.

Israel launching its own exercise could be about intimidating Palestine on the way into negotiations (Olmert met with Abbas yesterday, for example). The assassination of the No. 2 leader of Hamas in Syria is not surprising: Israel assassinates every leader it can find, for starters – anytime, anywhere. It is a despicable policy, and one the U.S. quietly condones.

So: the worry to me is the election. Does Israel feel that it must cash in the rest of its neocon chips now, and get the U.S. deeper into its “mine enemies are thine enemies” program?

If so, these are indeed risky times.

It would be simpler if I thought the U.S. actions were being taken solely on the basis of our own national interest.

Mark Anderson
